body.class: mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr mw-hide-empty-elt ns-6 ns-subject page-File_Spectrum_of_Sunlight_en_svg rootpage-File_Spectrum_of_Sunlight_en_svg skin-vector action-view skin-vector-legacy

a.title: This is a file from the Wikimedia Commons

img.alt: This is a file from the Wikimedia Commons

div.div: Size of this PNG preview of this SVG file: 800 × 424 pixels. Other resolutions: 320 × 170 pixels | 640 × 339 pixels | 1,024 × 542 pixels | 1,280 × 678 pixels | 2,560 × 1,356 pixels | 925 × 490 pixels.

div.p: Original file ‎(SVG file, nominally 925 × 490 pixels, file size: 121 KB)

tr.td:
This is a file from the Wikimedia Commons. Information from its description page there is shown below.
Commons is a freely licensed media file repository. You can help.

td.div: English: spectrum of sunlight; direct, overcast, and indirect (blue sky)

td.p: Data is from X-Rite i1Pro (118 sensor values between 350-740nm, Excel produced the graph, it was exported to PDF using Microsoft Office PDF export and tweaked with Illustrator and converted to SVG with Inkscape. Errors introduced by Inkscape were corrected by hand.

div.div: English: This is Illustrator (v.13) produced SVG ... It opens cleanly in Inkscape (except for fonts) but recoding by Inscape seems to cause problems with the Wikipedia SVG renderer. The Inkscape SVG code seems good, but I got no end of problems with getting it to render correctly on Wikipedia. Also, Adobe seems to have given up on producing decent SVG code with Illustrater CS6 (v. 16). I will have to try Illustrator CC. The problems are with the text and the gradient. The graph itself is fine. I also tried Visio for SVG output. It is part of Office, but nevertheless failed completely to deal with a simple Excel chart (ie. resorted to making bitmaps -- of course without letting you know!).

div.style: clear:both; margin:0.5em auto; background-color:#eee; border:2px solid #ddd; padding:8px; direction: ltr;

tr.td: This image is annotated: View the annotations at Commons

div.p: should show a simple gradient ... if someone can fix this.

17:48, 26 August 2015938 × 531 (72 KB)Txbangertwhy in gods name is some text font-size 9px (specified in px) while others is just a number? This confuses IE and Firefox.
17:38, 26 August 2015938 × 531 (72 KB)Txbangertworks in chrome but not in IE or firefox ... cut more Inkscape junk.
